0.title: Adult Dosing
0.mono: Mucositis following chemotherapy, In patients requiring stem cell transplant; Prophylaxis: 60 mcg/kg/day IV bolus for 3 consecutive days before (the third dose should be within 24 to 48 hours of starting myelotoxic therapy) and 3 consecutive days after myelotoxic therapy (first of these doses should be administered after, but on the same day of hematopoietic stem cell infusion and more than 4 days after the final dose of the initial dosing sequence); a total of 6 doses is given

1.title: Pediatric Dosing
1.mono: safety and effectiveness in pediatric patients have not been established

3.title: Indications
3.mono:
FDA-Labeled Indications
Mucositis following chemotherapy, In patients requiring stem cell transplant; Prophylaxis
Non-FDA Labeled Indications
Mucositis following chemotherapy, In patients with solid tumor malignancies; Prophylaxis

sub.title: Contraindications
sub.mono: Specific contraindications have not been determined

sub.title: Precautions
sub.mono:
• Other:
  • -- Administration may stimulate non-hematopoietic tumor growth
  • Concomitant Use:
  • -- Use not recommended with melphalan 200 mg/m(2) as a conditioning regimen
  • -- Do not administer within 24 hours before, during, or within 24 hours after myelotoxic chemotherapy due to risk of increased severity and duration of oral mucositis

sub.title: Breast Feeding
sub.mono: Micromedex: Infant risk cannot be ruled out.

5.title: Adverse Effects
5.mono:
Common
  • Cardiovascular:Edema (28%)
  • Dermatologic:Erythema (32%), Pruritus (35%), Rash (62%)
  • Gastrointestinal:Abdominal pain, Enlargement of tongue, Increased serum lipase level (28%), Loss of appetite, Serum amylase raised (overall, 62%; grade 3 and 4, 38%), Taste sense altered (hematologic malignancy, 16%;), Tongue discoloration, Vomiting
  • Musculoskeletal:Arthralgia (10%)
  • Neurologic:Dysesthesia (12%)
  • Other:Fever (39%), Pain (16%)
Serious
Gastrointestinal:High lipase level in serum (grade 3 and 4 elevation, 11%)

7.title: Mechanism Of Action
7.mono: Palifermin, a human keratinocyte growth factor (KGF) produced by recombinant DNA technology, is an endogenous protein in the fibroblast growth factor (FGF) family. Palifermin binds to the KGF receptor, causing proliferation, differentiation, and migration of epithelial cells.

9.title: Administration
9.mono:
Intravenous
  • add sterile water for injection to vial for a final concentration of 5 mg/mL, gently swirl, do not shake or vigorously agitate vial; dissolution can take up to 3 minutes
  • (bolus) give reconstituted solution immediately or store protected from light (in carton) for a maximum of 1 hour at room temperature or 24 hours if refrigerated
  • do not filter reconstituted solution during preparation or administration
  • if heparin is used to maintain the IV line, flush with saline prior to and after the dose to prevent binding to heparin

10.title: Monitoring
10.mono: symptomatic improvement, decreased mouth and throat soreness

13.title: Clinical Teaching
13.mono:
• Drug may cause thickening or discoloration of the tongue, altered taste, arthralgia, dysesthesia, pain, or fever.
  • Instruct patient to report signs/symptoms of cutaneous toxicity (pruritus, rash, edema, erythema).
